subject: History
title: Pasteur Kills the Myth of Spontaneous Generation
description: A short lesson to help you apply Pasteur Kills the Myth of Spontaneous Generation.

hook.text: For centuries, people believed maggots appeared from rotten meat and mice from grain. Louis Pasteur proved them wrong.

buildup.text: Spontaneous generationâ€”life arising from non-living matterâ€”was widely accepted into the 19th century.

discovery.text: Pasteur's swan-neck flask experiment (1859) showed that broth stayed sterile when shielded from airborne microbes.

twist.text: His work didn't just disprove an old mythâ€”it established germ theory, revolutionizing medicine and food safety.

climax.text: Pasteurization, named after him, still protects milk and juice today. His work saves millions of lives every year.

punchline.text: He proved that life only comes from life.

quiz.question: What did Pasteur's swan-neck flask experiment demonstrate?
options: That heat can create new microorganisms
That broth stays sterile when shielded from airborne microbes
That certain chemicals can generate life spontaneously
